objinfo.numberleaves: 1The letter was written on one side of a single leaf. Bentley (Writings volume 2, page 1523) notes that the address may have appeared on a cover which would have held the letter.

provenance.name: Cumberland Papers
provenance.note: George Cumberland; bequeathed to his son, George Cumberland; presented to the British Library in 1849, as part of the Cumberland Papers consisting of thirty-one volumes and two rolls, on condition that these should not be opened until 1900.

desc.objtitle: I have lately had some pricks of conscience, Object 1

objnote.p: The letter was written on one side of a single leaf. Bentley (Writings volume 2, page 1523) notes that the address may have appeared on a cover which would have held the letter.
In the top right corner the British Library folio number, "155", is inscribed in an unknown hand.

lg.l: Dear Cumberland
I have lately had some pricks of conscience on account
of not acknowledging your friendship to me before immediately
on the receitreceipt of your . beautiful book. I have likewise had byErdman (page 700) reads "receit" as "reciet".

me all the Summer 6 Plates which you desired me to getKeynes (Letters, page 6) and Erdman (page 700) read "Summer" as "summer". Bentley (Writings volume 2, page 1523) notes: "These six plates have not been identified, but one may be connected with Richard Cosway's suggestion of 27 Dec. 1795 that Cumberland should 'get Blake to make an engraving' of Cumberland's beautiful 'Picture of [i.e. by] Leonardo' (Blake Records, 49). More probably they were just blank copperplates which Cumberland had asked Blake to buy for him."
made for you. they have laid on my shelf, without speakingBentley (Writings volume 2, page 1523) reads "they" as "They".
to tell me whose they were or that they were there at all &
it was some time (when I found them) before I could divine
whence they came or whither they were bound or whether they
were to lie there to eternity. I have now sent them to you
to be transmuted, thou real AlchymistAlchemist!
Go on Go on. such works as yours Nature &Keynes (Letters, page 6) reads "such" as "Such".
Providence the Eternal Parents demand from their children
how few produce them in such perfection how Nature
smiles on them. how Providence rewards them. How all
your Brethren say, The sound of his harp & his flute heard
from his secret forest chearscheers us to the labours of life, &
we plow & reap forgetting our labour.
Let us see you sometimes as well as sometimes hear
from you & let us often See your Works
Compliments to Mrs Cumberland & Family
Lambeth Yours in head & heart
23 Decembr 1796
WillWilliam Blake
a Merry Christmas
